qas.question: Which family member commonly sent an adult married offspring away with their portion of the families fortune?
What type of document could be produced to distribute some of an inheritance?
How did daughters get their portion of the family fortune?
Was is guaranteed that a first born son would receive all of the family's fortune?

answers.text: inheritance practices did not involve primogeniture

qas.question: What type of title could be passed down?

context: Apart from the passing of <a4_0>noble<a4_0/> titles or ranks, <a3_0>inheritance practices did not involve primogeniture<a3_0/>; each son received an equal share of the family property. Unlike the practice in later dynasties, <a0_0>the father<a0_0/> usually sent his adult married sons away with their portions of the family fortune. Daughters received a portion of the family fortune through their <a2_0>marriage dowries<a2_0/>, though this was usually much less than the shares of sons. A different distribution of the remainder could be specified in <a1_0>a will<a1_0/>, but it is unclear how common this was.
